Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: A Multimodal Sensor Platform for Automated Detection and Classification of Pest Insects
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is significant. The proposed technology could drastically improve the overall effectiveness of pest management programs in various agricultural industries. The proposed system not only eliminates one of the most laborious and dreaded activities of manually inspecting insect traps, but also provides unprecedented access to accurate, real-time insect population information to make more effective pest management decisions. This leads to reduced, spatially-restricted pesticide applications, better understanding of insect pest behaviors, and enhanced biological control. The automated trap?s ability to monitor more than one species of insect not only achieves a higher level of efficiency in pest monitoring but also multiplies the technology?s value to the end users. The potential market for the proposed technology is quite broad. In fact, the technology can benefit any industry that requires regular monitoring of insect populations. Furthermore, the proposed technology could be used for various state and federal pest monitoring programs, such as the Slow the Spread (STS) Project administered by USDA to monitor gypsy moths.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase 2 project proposes to develop a multi-modal sensor platform for robust detection and classification of multiple insect pest species for automated monitoring of insect populations in production agriculture. The main goal of this project is two-fold: First is to demonstrate that bio-impedance sensor alone provides useful data to classify multiple insect species. A linear support vector machine classifier using mel-frequency cepstral coefficients extracted from bio-impedance data will be implemented on an embedded platform for detection and classification of two insect pest species. These bio-impedance based electronic traps will undergo large-scale field trials and be prepared for full commercialization. The second objective is to develop a multi-modal electronic trap with ultrasound, infrared and bio-impedance sensors that can simultaneously monitor four or more insect pest species. Measurement signals generated by the sensors will be analyzed to determine a set distinct features that can be computed on an embedded platform for real-time processing. These features will then be used in multi-modal sensor fusion algorithms for robust detection and classification. Different sensor fusion strategies will be investigated and the performance of each fusion algorithm will be evaluated both in controlled and field conditions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scott Williams concluded work on "A Multimodal Sensor Platform for Automated Detection and Classification of Pest Insects" supported by a Small Business Innovation and Research Grant from the NSF. An entomologist, Williams pursued an investigation on the use of automated monitoring technologies developed by Spensa Technologies, Inc. founder, Johnny Park, before the company's aquisition by DTN in March 2018. This work was founded on the idea that automated monitoring traps can provide information to growers about pest situations in their fields that improves management decisions. This in turn improves the profitability of grower operations in a period when manpower is increasingly limited and aging in the agricultural sector.

The work conducted by Williams and Spensa Technologies (now part of DTN) focused on how to deploy automated trapping technologies in a manner effective for the pest management needs of American growers. With precision agriculture growing as an industry, testing which technologies work and how they can be best applied can benefit the industry as it matures. Additionally, specific technologies, like the Z-trap, provide insights into insect behavior, such as real-time resolution of flight behavior, that is absent from the existing methods of trapping. DTN's Camera Smart trap is also helping advance the dataset for visually-recognizing insect pests, which may add in future pest identification technologies. Specifically, the work performed by Williams helped demonstrate that automated trapping technologies performed equally-well to existing trapping devices, but with the added bonus of being able to report information directly to the grower from a remote location. The data collected from this work was also incorporated to determine the distance required between traps to sample distinct populations of a pest; information that may guide the design of region-wide trapping networks in the future.

Beyond the basic application of the technology, the growing development of automated technologies will help change the approach of agricultural management. Better understanding the limits of the technologiy and how to disseminate the information it collects can potentially be expanded to other services. But in the more immediate scope, the promise of automated trapping technologies is a more accurate and precise form of pest management that reduces waste, environmental harm, and promotes human health and nutrition.

This work demonstrates that automated trapping technologies can be a viable and reliable tool for pest management and can continue to grow with time.
